SEARCH
Package civitas.celestis.util.group

Interface Grid<E>

Type Parameters:
E - The type of element this grid should hold
All Superinterfaces:
Collectable<E>, Group<E>, Iterable<E>, Mappable<Grid.Index,E>, Serializable, Transformable<E>
All Known Subinterfaces:
BigMatrix<N,M>, RawDoubleMatrix<M>, RawLongMatrix<M>
All Known Implementing Classes:
ArrayGrid, LongMatrix, Matrix
public interface Grid<E> extends Group<E>, Mappable<Grid.Index,E>, Iterable<E>
A m * n grid-like structure of objects.

Grids have a horizontal size (the number of columns) and a vertical size (the number of rows). The product of these two sizes yields the area of this grid.

Grids can be traversed and/or accessed by either providing the row and column index separately, or by providing an Index.

Grids can also be converted to a Map of Index and Grid by calling Mappable.map().

See Also:
  • Index
  • ArrayGrid
  • Matrix
  • LongMatrix
  • BigMatrix
  • Group
  • Mappable

    • indexOf

      @Nonnull static Grid.Index indexOf(@Nonnull Tuple<Integer> t)
      Returns an Index object constructed from the provided tuple of integers. The tuple must be a tuple of size 2, and the first and second component corresponding to row and column respectively.
      Parameters:
      t - The tuple of which to construct ths index object with

    • subGrid

      @Nonnull Grid<E> subGrid(int r1, int c1, int r2, int c2) throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
      Returns a sub-grid of this grid. The return value will have a row count of r2 - r1, and a column count of c2 - c1.
      Parameters:
      r1 - The starting point's row index
      c1 - The starting point's column index
      r2 - The ending point's row index
      c2 - The ending point's column index
      Returns:
      The sub-grid of the specified range
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - When the range is out of bounds

    • subGrid

      @Nonnull Grid<E> subGrid(@Nonnull Grid.Index i1, @Nonnull Grid.Index i2) throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
      Returns a sub-grid of this grid. The return value will have a row count of i2.x() - i1.x(), and a column count of i2.y() - i1.y().
      Parameters:
      i1 - The starting point's index
      i2 - The ending point's index
      Returns:
      The sub-grid of the specified range
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - When the range is out of bounds

    • transpose

      @Nonnull Grid<E> transpose()
      Returns a new grid where the rows and columns are inverted. The values are mapped according to the function f(p{x, y}) -> p{y, x}.
      Returns:
      The transpose of this grid

      c - The number of columns the new grid should have

    • merge

      @Nonnull Grid<E> merge(@Nonnull Grid<E> g, @Nonnull BiFunction<? super E,? super E,E> f) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Merges this grid with another grid of the same dimensions. The merger function f is applied to each component, and the resulting grid is returned.

      For example, if a sum function (x, y) -> x + y was provided, this would return the sum of the two grids of numbers.

      Parameters:
      g - The other grid to merge with
      f - The merger function to apply
      Returns:
      The resulting grid
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When the provided grid g's dimensions do not match to this grid's dimensions

    • equals

      boolean equals(@Nullable Object obj)
      Checks for equality between this grid and the provided object obj.
      Specified by:
      equals in interface Group<E>
      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
      Parameters:
      obj - The object to compare to
      Returns:
      true if the other object is also a grid, and the dimensions, composition of elements, and the order of elements all match
